The Dawn of Astronomy is a remarkable work: inspired astronomy mixed with distinctly flawed archaeology, which is an exceptional source, if handled carefully, for an understanding of the Egyptian capacity for exploring the heavenly bodies. Lockyer examines the orientation of a number of important Egyptian temples, including Karnak and Denderah, and concludes that their orientation was changed to perpetuate the temple’s lock NOTES 225 on to a particular star to which it was aligned when it was originally constructed
